div.div:
Due to the COVID-19 Pandemic, Diller-Odell Public Schools will be closed through May 31st.
School facility use, such as the fitness centers will also be closed during this time.

div.em: Current conditions as of 19 Apr 13:55 pm CDT

div.div: Sunny, with a high near 65. Northeast wind around 11 mph.

A 30 percent chance of showers, mainly after 2am. Partly cloudy, with a low around 40. East northeast wind 5 to 7 mph becoming light and variable. New precipitation amounts of less than a tenth of an inch possible.

A 20 percent chance of showers before 9am. Partly sunny, then gradually becoming sunny, with a high near 70. Light and variable wind becoming northwest 12 to 17 mph in the morning. Winds could gust as high as 28 mph.

p.span: Our Virtual Spirit Week was a great way for us to see all of the smiling Griffin faces again!

span.b: THE FUTURE IS SO BRIGHT DAY

a.aria-label: Read more about Virtual Spirit Week Highlights

h3.a: Diller-Odell Welcomes New Teachers for the 2020-2021 School Year

span.span: My name is Emmie Noyd. I was born and raised in Shelby, NE. I loved being brought up in a small-town community and I look forward to being a part of yours. I earned my Bachelor of Early Childhood Inclusive Education from Concordia University in Seward, NE. During my time at Concordia, I was also a part of the volleyball team and those experiences with that program has helped shaped me into who I am today. I am honored to be given the opportunity to teach third grade at Diller- Odell Public Schools, this coming school year. I am looking forward to making the connections with my students and families. I will also be taking on the assistant volleyball coach position. I am so excited to have the opportunity to share my love for the game and help this program to continue its success. My family is one of the most important things in my life. I enjoy spending time with my family, friends, camping, playing sports, and reading. I am proud to become a Diller- Odell Griffin!

p.span: Hello! My name is Deena Day and I will be the new Math Teacher at Diller-Odell High School! I earned my Bachelor's Degree from UNK, and my Master's Degree from Peru State College. I started my career at Lewiston High School, where I taught grades 8-12 and was assistant GBB and track coach for 7 years. I then moved to southeast Kansas; teaching and coaching volleyball and softball at Allen Community College and Fort Scott Community College. Although I enjoyed teaching at the college level, I prefer the junior high/high school level. The rapport and relationships that are developed not only with the students, but also with their families and the community, cannot be compared. For that reason, I accepted a teaching position at Iola High School. I stayed there for 14 years, teaching various math courses for grades 9-12, and also coaching volleyball. In 2014, after my 3 children Misty, Mindy and Tyler all graduated and were busy with their careers and families, I decided to move back home, to Odell. Since then, I have been substitute teaching at DOHS and a few surrounding schools. I am living on the farm I grew up on, enjoying being back home and am truly excited about teaching at the school I graduated from!!!
GO GRIFFS!!!!!

Hello all! My name is Brooke Frederick and I am very excited to be Diller Odell's new K-12 Art Teacher for the 2020-2021 school year. I recently received my Bachelors Degree at the University of Nebraska at Kearney. I grew up in Kearney and am excited to make the move to a smaller community.

I will be getting married next summer to my fiancé Taylon and have a puppy named Belly. In my spare time, I enjoy spending time with friends and family, helping on Taylon's family ranch, making art, whether that's drawings or paintings, and photography.
I am very thankful for this teaching position and am excited to meet all of the teachers, students, and community.

span.span: I grew up in Elmwood, NE attending Elmwood-Murdock Public Schools, a district only slightly larger than Diller-Odell. While at Elmwood-Murdock I had a wonderful school librarian who inspired me to become one myself. I am in the process of finishing my Bachelor’s of Science in Elementary Education from University of Nebraska at Omaha with an endorsement in K-12 School Library. This will enable me to be your new school librarian in August of 2020!

When I have time to myself I enjoy reading books of all kinds. My all time favorite children’s book is Percy Jackson and the Lightning Thief by Rick Riordan, but I am constantly looking for new favorites to add to my list. I also enjoy taking walks with my dog, Lucy, spending time with my friends and family, and exploring new places.
I am looking forward to getting the chance to explore the Diller-Odell community and meet all my fellow staff members and students in the coming years. Go Griffins!

p.span: My name is Michelle Weyer. I am currently in my seventh year of teaching. I began my teaching career in 2013 at Lewiston Consolidated Schools, and the past two years I have been teaching at Meridian Public School. In my teaching career I have taught elementary special education and first grade. I have also coached volleyball and basketball.
I graduated from UNK in 2012 with my bachelor's degree in early childhood unified and in 2016 with my master's degree in special education.
I am married to Devin and we have two children, Revel and Archer.
My hobbies include spending time with my family, sports, traveling, and scrapbooking.

span.span: Toni Landenberger was absent for roll call, but arrived at the meeting at 7:42pm.
Recognize the Open Meetings Act information
Motion to approve minutes of last meeting Passed with a motion by Gary Stohs and a second by Adam Engelman.
Angie Clifford: Yea, Adam Engelman: Yea, Paul Kostal: Yea, Jill Scheele: Yea, Gary Stohs: Yea
There was not a student report available

Principal Mezger gave an update on instruction during the school shut down. He noted he was very pleased with the effort of both students and staff and how they have engaged in the necessary changes brought upon them.
The Board discussed graduation. Due to the directed health measure by the Governor,
graduation will not be held on May 16. The Board will discuss the topic at the May meeting, with the hope that the traditional ceremony can be held in either June or July.
Prom was also discussed. Graduation is given first priority, but Prom is something that we hopefully can schedule in July.

Amend Policy #5006 to allow option families to host foreign exchange students Motion to amend policy #5006 to allow option families to host foreign exchange students. Passed with a motion by Jill Scheele and a second by Toni Landenberger.
Angie Clifford: Yea, Adam Engelman: Yea, Paul Kostal: Yea, Toni Landenberger: Yea, Jill Scheele: Yea, Gary Stohs: Yea
Approve teaching contract for Emmie Noyd
Motion to approve teaching contract for Emmie Noyd Passed with a motion by Angie Clifford and a second by Adam Engelman.
Angie Clifford: Yea, Adam Engelman: Yea, Paul Kostal: Yea, Toni Landenberger: Yea, Jill Scheele: Yea, Gary Stohs: Yea
Ms. Noyd will be teaching third grade and serve as the assistant volleyball coach.
Motion to re-elect certified staff with the exception of those notified of non-renewal Passed with a motion by Toni Landenberger and a second by Gary Stohs.
Angie Clifford: Yea, Adam Engelman: Yea, Paul Kostal: Yea, Toni Landenberger: Yea, Jill Scheele: Yea, Gary Stohs: Yea
Motion to approve a three percent salary increase for classified staff for 2020-21 Passed with a motion by Angie Clifford and a second by Jill Scheele.
Angie Clifford: Yea, Adam Engelman: Yea, Paul Kostal: Yea, Toni Landenberger: Yea, Jill Scheele: Yea, Gary Stohs: Yea
The Board reviewed extra duty assignments for 2020-21
The Board would like to give a special thanks to Diode Communications for making internet available free of charge to area families thru June 1, 2020 to new customers.

Superintendent Meyerle noted some summer facility projects that consist of: painting the outside of the old HS gym on the south side, two rooms of carpet replacement, and some window replacement in the older part of the elementary building.
Superintendent Meyerle noted that the budget was consistent with the past years at this point in the fiscal year.

The Board discussed an email from Senator Mike Groene. Superintendent Meyerle noted that the members of the Board of Education of Diller-Odell Public Schools know more about the needs of the school district more than state senators.
Motion to approve bills as presented. Passed with a motion by Gary Stohs and a second by Angie Clifford.
Angie Clifford: Yea, Adam Engelman: Yea, Paul Kostal: Yea, Toni Landenberger: Yea, Jill Scheele: Yea, Gary Stohs: Yea

The Board thanks the staff of Diller-Odell Public Schools for their efforts during this shutdown of the school. They recognize that the staff is doing a good job of continuing to educate our students while they cannot be in the buildings.
Motion to adjourn Passed with a motion by Toni Landenberger and a second by Adam Engelman.
Angie Clifford: Yea, Adam Engelman: Yea, Paul Kostal: Yea, Toni Landenberger: Yea, Jill Scheele: Yea, Gary Stohs: Yea
President Kostal adjourned the meeting at 8:28pm. The next regular Board meeting is scheduled for May 11, at 7:30pm

a.aria-label: Read more about April Board of Education Meeting

p.span: Hey, Griffins! Even though we can't gather together right now, we can show our Griffin Pride!
Join us next week for a Virtual Spirit Week!
Your teachers will be sharing posts for each day of the Spirit Week. Post your pictures of how you are dressing for Spirit Week.
Also, if you parents would like to, have them share your photos with Mrs. Coufal (acoufal@dillerodell.org) and she will post them on our social media accounts.

u.strong: Junior High and High School Students

p.span: Share your photos with Mrs. Coufal (acoufal@dillerodell.org) and she will post them on our social media accounts.

a.aria-label: Read more about Virtual Spirit Week-April 13th-17th

span.span: During this COVID-19 pandemic, the health and safety of students, staff and our community is our priority. With the announcement of the school building being closed through May 1st, Diller-Odell staff and administrators have been working to develop a plan of continuity for educating our students. While we understand that this will not replace the face-to-face interactions we are all used to, we do believe that the plan below will help our students continue learning. We realize that the current situation has and will continue to put unwanted strain on your family dynamics, but we do believe that it is beneficial for students to continue to engage in academic activities.

“Learning at Home-The Griffin Way!” is the plan we have developed to continue to serve the students of Diller-Odell Public Schools. Hopefully this plan will allow students to receive support with both materials and contact with their teachers. This is something new to all of us. Please understand that we are doing what we feel is best for students in this situation. We may discover that we need to modify this plan to better help the students and your families during this time. Thank you for your patience and support!
Although we are not requiring the following activities, we strongly suggest that your students engage in as many academic activities as possible. The following details will begin April 6th.
Teachers will prepare packets for each week of April with ENRICHMENT activities for students to complete.
Teachers will post once daily to Seesaw (or Class Dojo for 5th grade) with other suggested activities.
Teachers will be available for “Office Hours” to assist students the following times:
Feel free to reach out to teachers for assistance during these times.

Once a week teachers will coordinate a short 15 minute Zoom meeting opportunity for students. This is not required, but encouraged as it will provide students a chance to talk with their classmates and teachers.

K-6 families can choose to pick up school devices to use at home during this time. Details about usage of school devices and how to use them to access enrichment activities and Zoom calls will be sent home.

font.span: If your family does not have home interent services, please read this aritlce about free service being provided by Diode Communications:

span.i: Elementary students will be picking up packets from teachers and technology devices (if families choose to take them home).

span.span: Families with last names beginning with A-M alphabetically
Families with last names beginning with N-Z alphabetically

-At pickup, we are needing to obtain parental consent to use Zoom (a video conferencing tool) and to take devices home. If a parent cannot attend pickup, please download this document, print and sign and send to pick-up, or call your child’s school office to make other arrangements.
CLICK HERE FOR PARENTAL CONSENT DOCUMENT

-Everyone will enter and exit by the Eagle and go directly to the gym to pick up supplies. No one will be allowed to enter any other part of the building. Promptly gather supplies and exit the building.
-We will be enforcing the no more than 10 people gathered together at a time regulations, so you may be asked to wait outside the school until others clear the building.
**IF YOU OR SOMEONE IN YOUR FAMILY IS ILL OR HAS VISITED A “HOT SPOT”, please make other arrangements for pickup!
Students will continue learning new content at the junior high and high school levels.

b.u: he following activities will be required for students in 7th-12th grades beginning April 6th:

span.span: Teachers will assign two assignments per week for each class. This work is required and will be graded. All work will be completed in Canvas, our online learning management system. Students are familiar with this tool.
An Online Learning Plan has been created for Daily Focus (see details below).
Teachers will be available for “Office Hours” to assist students the following times:
Feel free to reach out to teachers for assistance during these times.

Once a week for each class that a student is in, the students will meet virtually in a Zoom meeting. This is not required, but encouraged as it will provide students a chance to talk with their classmates and teachers. Students will be provided detailed directions on how to access the meetings in their Canvas courses.
Junior High and High School students will need all books, computers and chargers (if they didn’t already take them home).
*if you have students in multiple grades, you may choose one time for your family
-Everyone will enter the main doors and will walk directly to the lockers, get books and essentials and promptly leave the building via the front doors.
-We will be enforcing the no more than 10 people gathered together at a time regulations, so you may be asked to wait outside the school until others clear the building.
**IF YOU OR SOMEONE IN YOUR FAMILY IS ILL OR HAS VISITED A “HOT SPOT”, please make other arrangements for pickup!

a.aria-label: Read more about Learning at Home-The Griffin Way!

p.span: Due to limiting contact, the office staff will be reducing our time in the buildings and will be working from home. We will be in and out of the building to check voicemail, mail, etc. Should you need anything when we are not here, do not hesitate to contact us via email or cell phone.

a.aria-label: Read more about Office Staff Hours

h3.a: COVID-19 Updates-Buildings closed through May 31st and Alternate Graduation Plans Will Be Made

span.span: On April 1, Governor Pete Ricketts announced Nebraska’s eighth Directed Health Measure (DHM). As part of this DHM, schools statewide are directed to operate without students in their buildings through May 31st. Extracurricular activities are cancelled statewide as well.

Traditional graduation ceremonies are not going to be possible this May. Diller-Odell Public Schools will be working to determine appropriate alternative methods to honor the Class of 2020, whether that be a ceremony at a later date or some other locally determined alternative graduation that complies with the guidance of health officials.

p.span: After consultation with our Health Department and other State and Local officials, it has been determined that Diller-Odell, and all schools in the ESU 5 Region will be closed through Friday, May 1st, with the possibility of schools being closed for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year. This decision will be re-evaluated as circumstances change, and another announcement will be made on April 22nd concerning the rest of the 2019-2020 school year. This is a precautionary public health measure; local health and school officials are monitoring the COVID-19 situation in Southeast Nebraska closely. School Superintendents met with Public Health Solutions and determined that this action would help prevent exposure to our area to flatten the curve and decrease the spread of disease.

Due to the COVID-19 Pandemic, Diller-Odell Public Schools, and the other ESU #5 schools will be closed to students Wednesday, March 18 through Tuesday, March 31. School facility use, such as the fitness centers will also be closed during this time. Staff may come in to their rooms as needed.

This decision has been reached after much discussion and deliberation with state and local authorities. We currently plan to resume school on Wednesday, April 1st but may need to extend that closure, based on the recommendations from health officials.

As always, our first priority is the safety and well-being of our students. We will continue to keep you informed should we need to extend the school closure. I have confidence that we have the best team in place to face this unprecedented challenge together. Thank you for your partnership and commitment to keeping our students and our community safe.

As noted, at this point we will remain in session, but until further notice we are not planning on any field trips. We also will not be allowing outside groups to use our facilities for alumni sports, youth sports, dinners etc.

Although due to the coronavirus many conferences and activities have been cancelled, our plan at Diller-Odell is to follow the Commissioner of Education's direction and continue having school at this time. Below is his statement:

span.i: UNLESS state or local health officials ask you to close, it is recommended that you hold school in your regular order. I believe there are community needs that your normal operations serve. HOWEVER, there are circumstances that schools have decided to close based on their own understanding of local community needs and I will try to support those decisions as well.

p.span: If a time comes that we know there is community spread of the virus, and school is not a safer place than being out and about, our plans could change.

a.aria-label: Read more about COVID-19 Updates-Buildings closed through May 31st and Alternate Graduation Plans Will Be Made

div.a: This institution is an equal opportunity provider.

div.style: color: #000; font-size: 11px; background-color: #fff; text-align: left; padding: 0 10px;
div.p: Diller-Odell Public Schools does not discriminate on the basis of race, color, national origin, sex, marital status, disability, or age or in admission or access to, or treatment of employment or educational programs, and activities.

The following person has been designated to handle inquiries regarding the School District’s non-discrimination policies: Mike Meyerle, who may be contacted in writing at 506 Perry Street, Odell, NE 68415; by e-mail: mmeyerle@dillerodell.org or by telephone at (402) 766-4210.

Any person may also contact the Office for Civil Rights, U.S. Department of Education, by email at OCR.KansasCity@ed.gov; by telephone at (816) 268-0550; or by fax at (816) 268-0599, regarding compliance with the regulations implementing Title VI, Title IX, Section 504, or any other applicable laws.
